section.title: Configuring AUTs to be started from the ITE
section.para: Once you have created a Project () and defined an AUT (), you can add and edit AUT configurations.
The details in the AUT configuration provide information on how to start the AUT, e.g. on which machine.

An AUT can have multiple configurations (for example, for local and remote testing). A configuration contains all the information required to start the AUT, and may contain platform- or installation-specific information such as paths to working directories, AUT arguments, Java versions, browser choices and activation methods.

In the AUT Configuration Dialog, it is possible to try to start the AUT using the entered configuration. This way it is possible to quickly check whether the configuration is correct. Use the Try AUT button for this. If the ITE is connected to an AUT Agent, that agent is used to start the AUT, otherwise the embedded Agent is started.
If you want to start your Java AUT yourself, and have the ITE connect to it, then use the autrun command to start the AUT (). In this case, you do not need to create an AUT configuration.

section.title: AUT activation
section.para: Activation makes sure that the AUT is in focus at the beginning of test execution. This is acheived by clicking somewhere in the AUT window. You can specify the activation method (i.e. where to click) as part of a configuration for an AUT, or you can create a Test Step within a test to do the same thing.
The advantage of specifying an activation method here is that it is central and affects each test execution started on this AUT with this configuration.
Bear in mind that you may need to activate your AUT in order for tests to work, especially if the AUT runs on the same machine as the ITE.
